snippet: Rules designed to guard the provenance of antiquities are creating difficulties for some collectors and museums in the donation, sale and purchase of those objects.
abstract: Rules designed to guard the provenance of antiquities are creating difficulties for some collectors and museums in the donation, sale and purchase of those objects; Assn of Art Museum Directors rules drawn up in 2008 have been applauded by countries seeking to recover their artifacts and by archaeologists looking to study objects in their natural settings, but has left collectors stuck with items that do not comply with the new guidelines and worried about the long-term cultural consequences.

byline.original: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL and TOM MASHBERG

lead_paragraph: Rules designed to guard the provenance of antiquities are creating difficulties for some collectors and museums in the donation, sale and purchase of those objects.

headline.seo: Antiquity Market Grapples With Stricter Guidelines for Gifts
headline.main: The Curse of the Outcast Artifact
